subject: Re: [junit] Strange request: examples of "beautiful" test code
msgSnippet: ... When you write a test method that starts with test , you are actually tagging extra information to your method to indicate that it s a tag, but you are
messageBody:
On 11/28/06, Stephen Smith <steve@...> wrote:
>
>
> I guess my skepticism of annotations when JSE5 was first released has
> unfortunately been transferred to JUnit 4 over time. Maybe I'm a bit
> stuck in my ways after writing so many JUnit 3.x test cases down the
> years?


When you write a test method that starts with "test", you are actually
tagging extra information to your method to indicate that it's a tag, but
you are doing it in a way that messes with your code.

You can't find a better use of annotations than that...

--
Cédric
http://testng.org


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
